title: 2 Samuel Chapter 15 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on 2 Samuel chapter 15 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: 2 Samuel Chapter 15 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of 2 Samuel Chapter 15.

questions.question: What did Absalom prepare for himself as mentioned in 2 Samuel 15:1?
options: Chariots and horses
A palace
A large army
A fleet of ships
questions.correctAnswer: Chariots and horses
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 15:1 states that Absalom prepared chariots and horses for himself.

questions.question: Where did Absalom stand early in the morning according to 2 Samuel 15:2?
options: Beside the way of the gate
At the city square
On the mountain
By the river
questions.correctAnswer: Beside the way of the gate
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 15:2 says Absalom rose early and stood beside the way of the gate.

questions.question: What did Absalom say he wished to be in the land in 2 Samuel 15:4?
options: Judge
King
Priest
General
questions.correctAnswer: Judge
questions.explanation: In 2 Samuel 15:4, Absalom said he wished to be made judge in the land.

questions.question: How did Absalom greet those who came to him according to 2 Samuel 15:5?
options: He took them by the hand and kissed them
He ignored them
He raised his hand in blessing
He gave them gifts
questions.correctAnswer: He took them by the hand and kissed them
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 15:5 describes how Absalom put forth his hand, took them, and kissed them.

questions.question: Where did Absalom say he wanted to go to pay his vow in 2 Samuel 15:7?
options: Hebron
Jerusalem
Giloh
Geshur
questions.correctAnswer: Hebron
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 15:7 says Absalom requested to go to Hebron to pay his vow.

questions.question: What was the condition of Absalom's vow mentioned in 2 Samuel 15:8?
options: If the LORD brings me again to Jerusalem
If I become king
If my enemies are defeated
If I see my father again
questions.correctAnswer: If the LORD brings me again to Jerusalem
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 15:8 states Absalom vowed to serve the LORD if he returned to Jerusalem.

questions.question: Who did Absalom send for to join his conspiracy as per 2 Samuel 15:12?
options: Ahithophel the Gilonite
Zadok the priest
Ittai the Gittite
Jonathan the son of Abiathar
questions.correctAnswer: Ahithophel the Gilonite
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 15:12 shows Absalom sent for Ahithophel, David's counselor, to join him.

questions.question: What did the messenger report to David about the hearts of the men of Israel in 2 Samuel 15:13?
options: Their hearts are after Absalom
Their hearts are loyal to David
Their hearts are divided
Their hearts are fearful
questions.correctAnswer: Their hearts are after Absalom
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 15:13 says the messenger reported the men of Israel's hearts were with Absalom.

questions.question: What instruction did David give to his servants in 2 Samuel 15:14?
options: To flee quickly from Absalom
To attack Absalom immediately
To negotiate peace with Absalom
To stay in the city and defend it
questions.correctAnswer: To flee quickly from Absalom
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 15:14 records David telling his servants to arise and flee to escape Absalom.

questions.question: Who did David leave behind to keep the house according to 2 Samuel 15:16?
options: Ten women who were concubines
His sons
His servants
His priests
questions.correctAnswer: Ten women who were concubines
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 15:16 states David left ten women, his concubines, to keep the house.

questions.question: True or False: According to 2 Samuel 15:21, Ittai the Gittite pledged to stay with David whether in death or life.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 15:21 shows Ittai pledging loyalty to David in life or death.

questions.question: True or False: Zadok and Abiathar carried the ark of the covenant out of the city with David as he fled in 2 Samuel 15:24.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 15:24 describes Zadok and Abiathar bearing the ark of the covenant out with David.

questions.question: True or False: According to 2 Samuel 15:30, David went up Mount Olivet with his head uncovered and wearing shoes.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 15:30 says David had his head covered and went barefoot as he went up Mount Olivet.

questions.question: Complete the verse from 2 Samuel 15:25: 'Carry back the ark of God into the city: if I shall find favour in the eyes of the LORD, he will bring me again, and shew me both it, and his ________.'
options: habitation
power
glory
mercy
questions.correctAnswer: habitation
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 15:25 states that God will show David both the ark and His habitation if He finds favor.

questions.question: According to 2 Samuel 15:37, who came into the city alongside Absalom?
options: Hushai David's friend
Ittai the Gittite
Ahithophel
Zadok the priest
questions.correctAnswer: Hushai David's friend
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 15:37 says Hushai David's friend came into the city with Absalom.

medium.title: 2 Samuel Chapter 15 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from 2 Samuel Chapter 15 to real-life situations.

questions.question: How does 2 Samuel 15 teach us about the importance of integrity in leadership through Absalom's actions?
options: Absalom showed integrity by genuinely serving the people
Absalom manipulated people by flattering them and stealing their hearts
Absalom prayed faithfully for the king's success
Absalom humbly submitted to the king's authority
questions.correctAnswer: Absalom manipulated people by flattering them and stealing their hearts
questions.explanation: Absalom prepared chariots and horses and used flattering words to gain favor and steal the hearts of the men of Israel (2 Samuel 15:1-6, 12-13). This shows a lack of integrity in leadership.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with trusting God during times of betrayal. Based on David's response in 2 Samuel 15, what biblical truth would you share?
options: Trust in human wisdom for protection
Flee from all challenges without prayer
Pray and ask God to turn the counsel of enemies into foolishness
Ignore the situation and hope it resolves itself
questions.correctAnswer: Pray and ask God to turn the counsel of enemies into foolishness
questions.explanation: David prayed to the LORD to turn the counsel of Ahithophel, who conspired with Absalom, into foolishness (2 Samuel 15:31), demonstrating reliance on God’s wisdom and protection in betrayal.

questions.question: What does David’s act of leaving concubines to keep the house teach about responsibility and stewardship in family life?
options: David abandoned his family with no care
David entrusted responsibility to others to maintain household order
David ignored his household duties
David took all household responsibilities himself
questions.correctAnswer: David entrusted responsibility to others to maintain household order
questions.explanation: David left ten women, his concubines, to keep the house when he fled (2 Samuel 15:16), showing wise stewardship by delegating responsibility during crisis.

questions.question: How does Ittai the Gittite's response to David teach about loyalty and perseverance in trials?
options: Ittai abandoned David when he was in trouble
Ittai pledged to stay with David in life or death
Ittai refused to help David
Ittai sought personal gain from the situation
questions.correctAnswer: Ittai pledged to stay with David in life or death
questions.explanation: Ittai declared he would go wherever David went, whether in life or death (2 Samuel 15:21), exemplifying loyalty and perseverance through trials.

questions.question: According to 2 Samuel 15, how can we apply humility and contentment in times of loss or crisis?
options: David wore a crown to show authority despite crisis
David went barefoot and covered his head while weeping, showing humility
David ignored the crisis and acted proud
David retaliated violently immediately
questions.correctAnswer: David went barefoot and covered his head while weeping, showing humility
questions.explanation: David went barefoot and covered his head, weeping as he went up Mount Olivet (2 Samuel 15:30), demonstrating humility and contentment even in hardship.

questions.question: How does Zadok's carrying of the ark of the covenant demonstrate faith and trust in God during difficult times?
options: Zadok ignored the ark and left it behind
Zadok carried the ark out of the city with faith in God's protection
Zadok destroyed the ark to prevent capture
Zadok hid the ark secretly
questions.correctAnswer: Zadok carried the ark out of the city with faith in God's protection
questions.explanation: Zadok and the Levites carried the ark of God as David fled, showing trust in God's presence and protection (2 Samuel 15:24-29).

questions.question: What lesson about prayer and dependence on God can we learn from David’s dialogue with Zadok regarding the ark?
options: David trusted only his own plans without God
David left the ark in the city and prayed to know if he had favor with God
David ignored God's presence during crisis
David destroyed the ark to stop the enemy
questions.correctAnswer: David left the ark in the city and prayed to know if he had favor with God
questions.explanation: David instructed Zadok to return the ark to the city and said if he found favor with the LORD, God would bring him back (2 Samuel 15:25-26), showing dependence on God’s will.

questions.question: How does Hushai the Archite’s strategy teach us about wise counsel and serving others in church life?
options: Hushai refused to help David
Hushai returned to the city to serve as a double agent for David
Hushai ignored David's request
Hushai betrayed David immediately
questions.correctAnswer: Hushai returned to the city to serve as a double agent for David
questions.explanation: David asked Hushai to return to Absalom and serve as his servant to defeat Ahithophel’s counsel (2 Samuel 15:32-34), illustrating wise, sacrificial service in ministry.

questions.question: A believer is feeling isolated after betrayal by close friends. Based on 2 Samuel 15, what example of faithfulness would you encourage them with?
options: Absalom’s betrayal is a reason to quit serving God
Ittai’s loyalty to David despite being a stranger
David immediately abandoned all his friends
David retaliated violently without prayer
questions.correctAnswer: Ittai’s loyalty to David despite being a stranger
questions.explanation: Ittai, a foreigner, pledged unwavering loyalty to David (2 Samuel 15:19-21), showing faithfulness even when isolated.

questions.question: How does David’s reaction to Absalom’s conspiracy teach about surrender and trust in God’s sovereignty?
options: David fled without any prayer or trust
David accepted the situation and prayed for God’s guidance
David fought Absalom immediately without counsel
David tried to negotiate peace himself
questions.correctAnswer: David accepted the situation and prayed for God’s guidance
questions.explanation: David fled Jerusalem but prayed for God to frustrate Ahithophel’s counsel (2 Samuel 15:31), showing surrender and trust in God’s sovereignty.

questions.question: What does Absalom’s request to go to Hebron to pay his vow reveal about the danger of disguising selfish ambition as religious devotion?
options: Absalom’s vow was a genuine act of worship without ulterior motives
Absalom used religious claims to advance his rebellion
Absalom openly declared his rebellion without disguise
Absalom avoided religious ceremonies
questions.correctAnswer: Absalom used religious claims to advance his rebellion
questions.explanation: Absalom asked to go to Hebron to pay a vow, but he secretly planned rebellion there (2 Samuel 15:7-10), showing how religious devotion can be misused for selfish ambition.

questions.question: True or False: David trusted Ahithophel completely even after he joined Absalom's conspiracy.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: David knew Ahithophel had joined Absalom’s conspiracy and prayed for God to make his counsel foolish (2 Samuel 15:31), showing David did not trust him.

questions.question: True or False: David’s servants were willing and ready to follow him when he decided to flee from Absalom.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: David’s servants assured him they were ready to do whatever he commanded (2 Samuel 15:15), reflecting faithful service and obedience.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: When David fled Jerusalem, he and all the people passed over the brook ________, toward the way of the wilderness.
options: Kidron
Jordan
Euphrates
Tigris
questions.correctAnswer: Kidron
questions.explanation: David crossed the brook Kidron as he fled the city with the people (2 Samuel 15:23), showing obedience to God’s leading during crisis.

questions.question: What practical lesson about serving others can be learned from Absalom’s approach to people who came to the king for judgment?
options: Absalom ignored people’s needs
Absalom welcomed and kissed those who came near him, gaining their favor
Absalom gave harsh judgments
Absalom sent people away without listening
questions.correctAnswer: Absalom welcomed and kissed those who came near him, gaining their favor
questions.explanation: Absalom put forth his hand and kissed people who came near (2 Samuel 15:5-6), showing how he sought to gain their hearts through personal attention, though for selfish motives.

hard.title: 2 Samuel Chapter 15 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from 2 Samuel Chapter 15.

questions.question: What was Absalom's initial strategy to win the hearts of the men of Israel according to 2 Samuel 15?
options: He prepared chariots and horses and fifty men to run before him
He stood by the gate and offered justice to those with disputes
He sent spies throughout the tribes of Israel
He kissed every man who came to him
questions.correctAnswer: He stood by the gate and offered justice to those with disputes
questions.explanation: Absalom positioned himself at the city gate and offered to hear the cases of people who came to the king for judgment, claiming he would give justice, thus winning their hearts (2 Samuel 15:2-4, 6).

questions.question: Which key figure defected to Absalom, strengthening his conspiracy, as mentioned in 2 Samuel 15?
options: Ahithophel the Gilonite
Ittai the Gittite
Zadok the priest
Abiathar the priest
questions.correctAnswer: Ahithophel the Gilonite
questions.explanation: Absalom called Ahithophel, David's counselor, to join his conspiracy, which greatly strengthened Absalom's cause (2 Samuel 15:12).

questions.question: How many years after David's reign did Absalom ask to go to Hebron to pay his vow?
options: Forty years
Twenty years
Ten years
Five years
questions.correctAnswer: Forty years
questions.explanation: The text mentions 'after forty years' Absalom asked the king to let him go to Hebron to pay his vow (2 Samuel 15:7).

questions.question: What was the content of Absalom's vow as he explained it to King David?
options: If the LORD brings me again to Jerusalem, I will serve the LORD
If the LORD grants me kingship, I will build a temple
If I defeat my enemies, I will sacrifice a bull
If the LORD blesses my family, I will give to the poor
questions.correctAnswer: If the LORD brings me again to Jerusalem, I will serve the LORD
questions.explanation: Absalom declared he vowed that if the LORD brought him again to Jerusalem, he would serve the LORD (2 Samuel 15:8).

questions.question: What role did the Cherethites, Pelethites, and Gittites play during David's flight from Jerusalem?
options: They passed on before the king as his guard
They betrayed David to Absalom
They carried the Ark of the Covenant
They stayed behind to defend the city
questions.correctAnswer: They passed on before the king as his guard
questions.explanation: The Cherethites, Pelethites, and Gittites, numbering six hundred men, passed before David as he fled, acting as his protectors (2 Samuel 15:18).

questions.question: Why did David initially urge Ittai the Gittite to return to his place instead of following him?
options: Because Ittai was a stranger and an exile
Because Ittai was wounded
Because Ittai was too young to fight
Because David wanted to spare Ittai from danger
questions.correctAnswer: Because Ittai was a stranger and an exile
questions.explanation: David told Ittai to return because he was a stranger and an exile, and David did not want to burden him with the flight (2 Samuel 15:19-20).

questions.question: How did Ittai respond to David's request to return during the flight from Jerusalem?
options: He pledged unwavering loyalty, saying he would go wherever David went
He agreed to return to his place
He asked for more time to consider
He left with some men but not all
questions.correctAnswer: He pledged unwavering loyalty, saying he would go wherever David went
questions.explanation: Ittai declared his loyalty to David, saying he would be with him in life or death wherever he went (2 Samuel 15:21).

questions.question: What was David's instruction to Zadok regarding the Ark of the Covenant during his flight?
options: Carry back the Ark to the city and wait for news
Take the Ark with him into the wilderness
Hide the Ark in a secret place
Give the Ark to Absalom
questions.correctAnswer: Carry back the Ark to the city and wait for news
questions.explanation: David instructed Zadok to carry the Ark back to Jerusalem and wait there until he received news, trusting in God's favor (2 Samuel 15:25, 28).

questions.question: What symbolic action did David perform as he went up the ascent of Mount Olivet?
options: He wept, covered his head, and went barefoot
He sacrificed a lamb
He prayed aloud to the LORD
He blew a trumpet
questions.correctAnswer: He wept, covered his head, and went barefoot
questions.explanation: David went up Mount Olivet weeping, with his head covered and barefoot, showing his humility and sorrow (2 Samuel 15:30).

questions.question: Who came to meet David at the top of Mount Olivet with his coat rent and earth upon his head?
options: Hushai the Archite
Ahithophel the Gilonite
Zadok the priest
Ittai the Gittite
questions.correctAnswer: Hushai the Archite
questions.explanation: Hushai the Archite came to meet David at the mount with signs of mourning, indicating his support (2 Samuel 15:32).

questions.question: What was David’s reasoning for sending Hushai back to Jerusalem instead of taking him along?
options: Hushai could better serve by opposing Ahithophel's counsel from within Absalom's court
Hushai was in poor health
David feared Hushai would betray him
Hushai had family in Jerusalem to protect
questions.correctAnswer: Hushai could better serve by opposing Ahithophel's counsel from within Absalom's court
questions.explanation: David sent Hushai back to act as a double agent to defeat Ahithophel's counsel by pretending to serve Absalom (2 Samuel 15:33-34).

questions.question: Who were the two sons mentioned as intermediaries for communication between Hushai and David?
options: Ahimaaz (son of Zadok) and Jonathan (son of Abiathar)
Ittai and Ahithophel
Absalom's son and David's son
Zadok and Abiathar
questions.correctAnswer: Ahimaaz (son of Zadok) and Jonathan (son of Abiathar)
questions.explanation: David instructed Hushai to communicate via Zadok's son Ahimaaz and Abiathar's son Jonathan (2 Samuel 15:35-36).

questions.question: True or False: According to 2 Samuel 15, Absalom’s conspiracy was unknown to David before he fled Jerusalem.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: David was informed that the hearts of the men of Israel were after Absalom, prompting him to flee (2 Samuel 15:13-14).

questions.question: Fill in the blank: The event of David leaving Jerusalem foreshadows the New Testament theme of the _______ of the Messiah who is rejected and flees from his enemies.
options: exile
crucifixion
resurrection
ascension
questions.correctAnswer: exile
questions.explanation: David's flight represents a typology of the Messiah's suffering and rejection, foreshadowing the Messiah's own experiences of exile (2 Samuel 15:14-16).

questions.question: How does Absalom’s act of kissing those who came to him for obeisance function as a literary device in this narrative?
options: It symbolizes political manipulation and false affection
It shows genuine love and loyalty
It is a ritual of covenant renewal
It marks a religious blessing
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes political manipulation and false affection
questions.explanation: Absalom's kisses are a form of political flattery used to steal the hearts of the people, indicating manipulation rather than genuine affection (2 Samuel 15:5-6).

theological.title: 2 Samuel Chapter 15 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from 2 Samuel Chapter 15 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What does Absalom's preparation of chariots, horses, and men to run before him (2 Samuel 15:1) signify theologically about his intentions?
options: He is preparing to establish his own authority and kingly power.
He is preparing for a peaceful pilgrimage to worship God.
He is organizing a defense to protect King David.
He is gathering servants for a royal banquet.
questions.correctAnswer: He is preparing to establish his own authority and kingly power.
questions.explanation: Absalom's preparation of chariots, horses, and men running before him demonstrates his intent to assert kingly authority, as seen in other biblical contexts where chariots and horses symbolize military or royal power (2 Samuel 15:1). This reflects themes of human ambition and rebellion against God-ordained authority (cf. 1 Samuel 8:7, Psalm 2:2, Isaiah 14:13-14, Revelation 19:19).

questions.question: How does Absalom's act of standing by the gate to hear the complaints of the people (2 Samuel 15:2-3) reveal about human sinfulness and the desire for power?
options: It shows manipulation and usurpation of rightful authority for personal gain.
It illustrates faithful service to the king.
It represents humility and service to the people.
It indicates Absalom's desire to resolve disputes peacefully.
questions.correctAnswer: It shows manipulation and usurpation of rightful authority for personal gain.
questions.explanation: Absalom's tactic of hearing complaints and promising justice reveals sinful ambition and manipulation of the people’s trust to gain power, contrary to God's ordained leadership (2 Samuel 15:2-3). This reflects human tendencies toward rebellion and self-exaltation (cf. Romans 3:23, James 4:6, Proverbs 16:18, Jeremiah 17:9, Isaiah 53:6).

questions.question: What is the significance of Absalom kissing those who came to him (2 Samuel 15:5) in the context of biblical symbolism?
options: It symbolizes deceitful affection to win loyalty.
It represents genuine love and reconciliation.
It is a customary greeting with no ulterior motive.
It signifies blessing from God upon his actions.
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes deceitful affection to win loyalty.
questions.explanation: Absalom's kissing those who came to him is a strategic act of deceit to win their hearts and loyalties, illustrating the sin of falsehood and manipulation (2 Samuel 15:5-6). This contrasts with genuine godly love and truth (cf. Matthew 24:4-5, John 8:44, Proverbs 26:24-26, 2 Timothy 3:13, Jeremiah 9:5).

questions.question: Why did Absalom request to go to Hebron to pay his vow (2 Samuel 15:7-8), and what theological theme does this reveal?
options: To fulfill a religious vow while plotting rebellion, showing hypocrisy.
To seek forgiveness from the Lord for his sins sincerely.
To unite the tribes of Israel in worship.
To escape from the king's judgment.
questions.correctAnswer: To fulfill a religious vow while plotting rebellion, showing hypocrisy.
questions.explanation: Absalom's vow and journey to Hebron represent religious hypocrisy, using worship as a cover for rebellion, highlighting the theme of false piety versus true devotion (2 Samuel 15:7-8). This reflects the biblical warning against superficial religion (cf. Isaiah 29:13, Matthew 15:8, Amos 5:21-24, James 1:26-27, 1 Samuel 15:22).

questions.question: What does the sending of spies and the trumpet sound to announce Absalom's reign (2 Samuel 15:10) teach about deception in the narrative?
options: It reveals the use of strategic deception to usurp the throne.
It is an act of open warfare declared honestly.
It shows a peaceful transition of power.
It is a ceremonial announcement with no real threat.
questions.correctAnswer: It reveals the use of strategic deception to usurp the throne.
questions.explanation: Absalom's use of spies and trumpet signals to declare his reign is a calculated deception to incite rebellion, illustrating the biblical theme of deceitfulness in human sinfulness (2 Samuel 15:10). This aligns with warnings about false leaders and deception (cf. Matthew 24:24, Proverbs 6:16-19, Jeremiah 9:5, 2 Corinthians 11:13-15, Revelation 13:14).

questions.question: What does King David's decision to flee Jerusalem (2 Samuel 15:14) reveal about divine providence and human response to rebellion?
options: It shows submission to God's sovereign will and prudent trust in His timing.
It is an act of cowardice and lack of faith.
It reflects a desire to abandon his responsibilities.
It indicates divine rejection of David as king.
questions.correctAnswer: It shows submission to God's sovereign will and prudent trust in His timing.
questions.explanation: David's flight is a strategic and humble recognition of the rebellion’s danger, trusting in God's providence while preserving life and the future of the kingdom (2 Samuel 15:14). This aligns with biblical examples of wise retreat and trust in God’s plan (cf. Exodus 14:13-14, Psalm 37:1-9, Proverbs 3:5-6, Romans 8:28, 1 Peter 5:6-7).

questions.question: Why did David leave ten concubines to keep the house (2 Samuel 15:16), and what does this signify about royal responsibility and covenantal order?
options: To maintain the king’s household and royal lineage in his absence.
To abandon them without care during the crisis.
To give them to Absalom as a sign of surrender.
To use them as political hostages.
questions.correctAnswer: To maintain the king’s household and royal lineage in his absence.
questions.explanation: David’s leaving concubines to keep the house reflects concern for the royal household and covenantal continuity despite political turmoil (2 Samuel 15:16). This shows the importance of preserving God-ordained social and familial structures (cf. Genesis 17:7, 2 Samuel 7:12-16, Psalm 89:3-4, Proverbs 20:7, 1 Timothy 3:4-5).

questions.question: What theological significance is found in Ittai the Gittite’s loyalty to David despite being a foreigner (2 Samuel 15:19-21)?
options: It demonstrates faithfulness that transcends ethnic boundaries.
It indicates political opportunism.
It shows disregard for David's cause.
It reveals confusion and misunderstanding.
questions.correctAnswer: It demonstrates faithfulness that transcends ethnic boundaries.
questions.explanation: Ittai’s loyalty shows that faithfulness and covenant loyalty can cross ethnic lines, foreshadowing the inclusion of Gentiles in God’s covenant people (2 Samuel 15:19-21). This is consistent with biblical themes of God's universal salvation plan (cf. Ruth 1:16-17, Isaiah 56:6-7, Acts 10:34-35, Galatians 3:28, Ephesians 2:11-22).

questions.question: What is the significance of the people weeping loudly as David leaves Jerusalem (2 Samuel 15:23) in terms of covenant community and leadership?
options: It expresses the people's grief for the disruption of God’s anointed king and covenant order.
It shows their joy for a new ruler.
It indicates indifference to the king’s departure.
It represents rebellion against David.
questions.correctAnswer: It expresses the people's grief for the disruption of God’s anointed king and covenant order.
questions.explanation: The loud weeping reflects sorrow for the broken covenant community and the upheaval of God’s ordained leadership (2 Samuel 15:23). This aligns with biblical respect for God’s anointed and the pain caused by rebellion (cf. Psalm 2:10-12, 1 Samuel 26:9-11, Jeremiah 22:3-5, Ezekiel 34:23-24, Hebrews 13:17).

questions.question: Why did David instruct Zadok to carry the ark back to the city (2 Samuel 15:25), and what theological hope does this express?
options: It expresses hope for restoration if God shows favor, trusting in divine mercy.
It shows abandonment of God's presence.
It indicates rejection of the temple worship.
It symbolizes surrender to Absalom.
questions.correctAnswer: It expresses hope for restoration if God shows favor, trusting in divine mercy.
questions.explanation: Sending the ark back signals David’s trust in God's favor and hope for restoration, acknowledging God's sovereign control over his fate (2 Samuel 15:25-26). This reflects biblical trust in God's mercy and covenant faithfulness (cf. Exodus 25:8-9, Psalm 51:1-2, Lamentations 3:22-23, Isaiah 40:31, Romans 8:28).

questions.question: What is the significance of David's mourning and going barefoot with his head covered (2 Samuel 15:30) in biblical symbolism?
options: It signifies deep grief and repentance before God.
It shows disrespect to the people.
It is a sign of physical weakness only.
It indicates celebration of a festival.
questions.correctAnswer: It signifies deep grief and repentance before God.
questions.explanation: David’s barefoot and covered head symbolize mourning and humility before God, common biblical signs of penitence and sorrow (2 Samuel 15:30). This is consistent with biblical expressions of grief and repentance (cf. Exodus 3:5, 2 Samuel 12:20, Job 1:20, Isaiah 58:5, Luke 18:13).

questions.question: What does David’s prayer asking God to turn Ahithophel’s counsel into foolishness (2 Samuel 15:31) reveal about divine sovereignty and human counsel?
options: God controls the outcome of human plans, protecting His anointed.
Human counsel is always superior to divine will.
Prayer has no effect on political events.
Ahithophel’s counsel is divinely inspired and unchangeable.
questions.correctAnswer: God controls the outcome of human plans, protecting His anointed.
questions.explanation: David’s prayer acknowledges God’s sovereign power over human schemes, emphasizing that divine providence can frustrate evil counsel (2 Samuel 15:31). This reflects biblical teaching on God's control of history and protection of His chosen (cf. Psalm 33:10-11, Proverbs 19:21, Isaiah 46:9-10, Acts 2:23, Romans 8:28).

questions.question: Why did David send Hushai back to the city as a spy (2 Samuel 15:32-37), and what does this teach about wise stewardship in crisis?
options: To use wisdom and discernment for God’s purposes in thwarting evil plans.
To abandon his followers and responsibility.
To surrender to Absalom without resistance.
To seek personal safety only.
questions.correctAnswer: To use wisdom and discernment for God’s purposes in thwarting evil plans.
questions.explanation: David’s sending of Hushai demonstrates prudent use of intelligence and strategy under God’s guidance to oppose rebellion (2 Samuel 15:32-37). This teaches stewardship of wisdom and faithful action amid trials (cf. Proverbs 2:6, Ecclesiastes 9:18, Matthew 10:16, James 1:5, Ephesians 6:10-18).

questions.question: How does Absalom’s conspiracy growing strong (2 Samuel 15:12) reflect the biblical theme of human rebellion against God’s anointed?
options: It illustrates the persistent human sin of undermining God’s chosen leaders.
It shows people’s desire for righteous leadership.
It indicates divine rejection of David.
It represents a peaceful political transition.
questions.correctAnswer: It illustrates the persistent human sin of undermining God’s chosen leaders.
questions.explanation: The strengthening conspiracy highlights the reality of human rebellion and opposition to God's anointed king (2 Samuel 15:12). This theme appears throughout Scripture (cf. 1 Samuel 8:7, Psalm 2:2, Isaiah 49:7, Acts 4:26-27, Hebrews 13:17).

questions.question: What does the role of Zadok and Abiathar carrying the ark and later returning it to Jerusalem (2 Samuel 15:24-29) indicate about the place of worship and God’s presence during crisis?
options: It shows that God’s presence remains in the temple despite political upheaval.
It means God has abandoned Jerusalem.
It indicates the ark is useless without David.
It signifies the end of Israelite worship.
questions.correctAnswer: It shows that God’s presence remains in the temple despite political upheaval.
questions.explanation: The priests’ actions demonstrate the continuing centrality of the ark and God’s presence in Jerusalem regardless of political instability (2 Samuel 15:24-29). This affirms the enduring nature of covenant worship (cf. Exodus 25:22, 1 Kings 8:10-11, Psalm 46:4-5, Jeremiah 7:4, Hebrews 9:11-12).

questions.question: What lesson about human loyalty and divine faithfulness can be drawn from the people of Israel following Absalom simply and unknowingly (2 Samuel 15:11)?
options: Human loyalty can be easily misled without discernment, highlighting the need for divine guidance.
People always follow the true king.
Loyalty is always based on good judgment.
Following Absalom was a sign of God's favor.
questions.correctAnswer: Human loyalty can be easily misled without discernment, highlighting the need for divine guidance.
questions.explanation: The people following Absalom in simplicity reveals human susceptibility to deception and the importance of spiritual discernment (2 Samuel 15:11). Scripture warns against blind loyalty and calls for wisdom from God (cf. Proverbs 14:15, Jeremiah 17:9, 1 Corinthians 2:14, Ephesians 5:15-17, Hebrews 5:14).
